awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Dissociating Perceptual and Motor Correlates of EEG Mu-Alpha and Beta Oscillations in Emotional Action Simulation
awd_abstract_narration:
From jumping jacks to jumping for joy, the "body language" of human movement provides
important information about the intentions and emotions of others. Growing evidence suggests
that we understand others' mental states by internally recreating, or simulating, their external
actions. Yet questions remain about how different brain systems contribute to action simulation,
and whether this process is linked to individual differences in social perception abilities. This
research uses electroencephalography (EEG) to examine brain activity associated with action
simulation during observation of emotional body movements, both in typically developing
individuals and in individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD), a condition associated with
social perception impairments. By testing the link between EEG measures of action simulation
and emotion perception capabilities across a broad sample of individual socio-emotional
functioning, these data will provide a rigorous theoretical framework for understanding the
neural basis of emotional action simulation. More broadly, the research may provide new
insights into the neural origins of social impairments observed in ASD, potentially leading to
improved diagnoses and therapies. Finally, these activities will promote undergraduate training
in the STEM disciplines by providing authentic research opportunities for students including
women and underrepresented minorities.

The proposed research will examine the relation between perceptual and motor circuits in
emotion simulation. In a previous EEG study, the investigators found distinct neural markers
associated with the observation of emotional and emotionally-neutral actions. Emotional actions
elicited a reduction of cortical "mu" alpha rhythms (9-12 Hz) linked to perceptual aspects of
action simulation, but neutral actions produced enhanced beta-band oscillations (14-20 Hz)
associated with motor planning and response inhibition. Both effects were attenuated in a nonclinical
sample of individuals reporting greater autistic tendencies, suggesting these neural
markers are sensitive to individual differences in social-emotional traits. The proposed research
will investigate the contribution of motor circuits to mu-alpha suppression for emotional actions
by comparing action execution with observed emotional action and varying the familiarity and
ease of simulating observed emotional actions. Examination of individuals with ASD will
distinguish how mu and beta band activity relate to individual differences in emotional
processing, allowing assessment of whether neurodevelopmental disruptions of sensorimotor
systems play a role in emotion simulation deficits. Collectively, these studies will provide
important insights into the relations between EEG measures, action simulation processes, and
emotion perception.

por.por_cntn:
From jumping jacks to jumping for joy, human body movements provide a rich source of information about people's intentions and emotions. This ability to understand others' body movements is usually rapid and automatic. However, individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) can have difficulty comprehending other people's body language, potentially contributing to issues with social perception and communication. Therefore, it is important to understand where and how body movement perception occurs in the brain.

One prominent theory of body movement perception is called action simulation theory. According to this theory, rather than relying solely on visual information to understand movements, we recruit our own motor systems, parts of the brain responsible for planning and executing actions. Evidence for this theory has come from studies using electroencephalography (EEG). EEG studies have identified a brain wave over motor areas, the mu-alpha rhythm, which is reduced when people perform actions such as finger tapping. Critically, this same reduction, or suppression, has been reported when motionless participants observe the actions of others. This supports the idea that the same brain areas contribute to both doing and viewing actions. Other studies have found smaller mu-alpha suppression in individuals with ASD compared to control participants, suggesting that action simulation may be affected in ASD.

However, this framework has recently come into question, as some studies didn't find mu-alpha suppression for action observation (AO). Many previous studies of mu-alpha suppression had methodological issues, such as using small numbers of participants, not matching the visual information for human actions vs. non-human motions, and not controlling participants' attention levels during the task. Also, very few studies looked at mu-alpha suppression for doing and viewing actions within the same participants. All of these issues made it difficult to say for sure that mu-alpha suppression really reflected action simulation. Also, because many studies used emotionally-neutral movements (like a hand opening and closing), another question was whether AO mu-alpha suppression would be visible for bodily expressions of emotion, the processing of which is impaired in ASD.

To examine these questions, we performed experiments measuring mu-alpha suppression in over a hundred participants while they viewed videos of whole-body movements that could be either neutral (like marching in place) or emotional (like shaking a fist in anger). To ensure that the motion information was the same, we used special animations called point-light displays (PLDs), where white markers were placed on the major joints but the rest of the screen was black. This creates an experience of watching a moving person, but without any other body shape information. We could compare these PLDs of meaningful body movements (Coherent condition) to randomized versions of the same movements, keeping all the motion the same but destroying the sense of body movement (Scrambled condition). We also had participants do a task so that they paid equal attention in both conditions. Finally, we had participants perform a separate finger-tapping condition, so that we could compare their mu-alpha suppression during doing and viewing of movements.

When we looked at our results, at first we were surprised to find no mu-alpha suppression for Coherent vs. Scrambled PLDs, even though participants showed a clear mu-alpha suppression during the finger-tapping task. This suggests that many of the previous results on mu-alpha suppression during action observation may have been affected by differences in brain activity unrelated to action simulation, such as visual motion processing or greater attention to human movements. However, during the time we were running the study, new data cleaning approaches were developed by other researchers. When we used these data cleaning approaches, we were able to recover a significant AO mu-alpha suppression effect. This effect was found at the same sensors as the finger-tapping activity, supporting the idea that AO mu-alpha suppression does reflect motor simulation.

Interestingly, this mu-alpha suppression effect was strongest for neutral, rather than emotional, body movements. This suggests that mu-alpha suppression may not fully explain problems with understanding emotional body language in conditions like ASD. Instead, other aspects of the EEG signal, like the peak frequency of the mu rhythm, may be better for distinguishing individuals with autistic traits. To understand differences between neutral and emotional body movement processing, we are currently investigating other measures of brain activity. 

We also conducted a study in which we collected people's own movements using motion-capture hardware, so we can see if there is more mu-alpha suppression for emotional movements that come from our own motor repertoire. This may occur because it is more difficult to simulate other people's emotional body movements, since different people convey bodily emotions in different ways.

In summary, our results provide limited support for mu-alpha suppression as a measure of action simulation. To better understand how body movement perception is affected by disorders like ASD, we may have to look at other signals from the brain.
